subsection.content: The Building Authority may upon application issue a permit to erect hoardings, covered walkways or gantries and may specify in the permit the period for which such hoardings, covered walkways or gantries may exist, and such other conditions as he may deem necessary.
If the permittee of such a permit fails to comply with any of these regulations or any of the conditions specified in the permit, the permit may be cancelled.

Every building owner shall erect hoardings, covered walkways and gantries in accordance with the permit issued under regulation 65 prior to the commencement of the building works specified in regulation 64, and shall maintain such hoardings, covered walkways and gantries in good repair during the continuance of the permit.
Except on isolated sites, all hoardings, unless exempted by the Building Authority, shall be close boarded.
No hoarding, covered walkway, gantry or building materials shall obstruct any drainage channel.
No advertisement other than a description of the building and the names of any persons concerned in its construction shall be displayed on any such hoarding or covered walkway.

Where any building owner fails to comply with any requirement made, pursuant to the provisions of regulation 65, by the Building Authority or with the provisions of regulation 66 or causes any damage to Government property in the erection or maintenance of such hoardings, covered walkways and gantries, the Building Authority may cause to be erected and maintained such hoardings, covered walkways and gantries as he may deem necessary and may carry out any work necessary to secure compliance with any requirement made pursuant to regulation 65, and may make good any such damage. (G.N.A. 83 of 1959; G.N.A. 75 of 1962)
The Building Authority may recover the cost of such work from the building owner.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Live wire or cable to be made safe
section.content: Where any hoarding, covered walkway or gantry is erected near to any live wire or cable, the permittee shall arrange with the owners of such wire or cable, to take the necessary precautions to render safe such wire or cable.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Deposit of security
section.text: The Building Authority may require any person, to whom a permit is issued to erect any hoarding, covered walkway or gantry in, over or upon Government land, to make a deposit in the Treasury of a sum not exceeding $500 as security for the fulfilment of all obligations of the permittee. The amount of the deposit shall be fixed by the Building Authority who shall consider the circumstances of each particular case.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Cancellation of permit
section.content: The Building Authority may in the public interest cancel any permit to erect and require the removal of any hoarding, covered walkway or gantry even if the permittee has fulfilled all his obligations.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Power of Building Authority to permit windows, etc. to face or ventilate into unenclosed verandah, etc.

subsection.content: Where, by any of these regulations, any window or vent or any other part of any building is required to face or to ventilate, directly or otherwise, into the external air or into the open air or any aperture or airshaft is required to communicate with the open air, the Building Authority may, subject to the provisions of paragraph (2), where he thinks fit, permit such window, vent or other part of any building, as the case may be, to face or to ventilate into, or such aperture or airshaft to communicate with, an unenclosed verandah or balcony or any other unenclosed place.

The Building Authority shall not give his permission under this regulation unless he is satisfied that to do so will not be to the prejudice of the standards of lighting or ventilation laid down by these regulations or the health of the occupiers of the building.
Where he gives his permission under this regulation, the Building Authority may, upon giving his approval of the plans of the building works, impose such conditions as he considers necessary.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Buildings to be planned for use by persons with a disability

subsection.content: Subject to paragraphs (3) and (4) and notwithstanding any other provisions (other than the provisions under this regulation) in these regulations, where a building is one to which persons with a disability have, or may reasonably be expected to have, access, that building shall be designed to the satisfaction of the Building Authority in such a manner as will facilitate the access to, and use of, that building and its facilities by persons with a disability. (L.N. 239 of 1997)
A building shall be deemed to be designed in accordance with paragraph (1) if its design complies with the requirements set out in Part 2 of the Third Schedule. (L.N. 124 of 2008)

The provisions of this regulation shall apply to the categories of buildings specified in the first column of Part 4 of the Third Schedule only to the extent specified in the second column thereof. (L.N. 124 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: The provisions of this regulation shall not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: buildings of 13 m or less in height above ground level which are used, or intended to be used, for occupation by a single family; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: temporary buildings or contractor’s sheds referred to in Part VII. (L.N. 239 of 1997)

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Schedule, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: access (通道) means any means that enable persons with a disability to approach, enter and leave the building and to use the facilities in the building without assistance or undue difficulties;

def.name: Accessible
def.leadIn: accessible (暢通易達), in relation to a site, building or facility or a portion of it, means the site, building, facility or portion—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: can be approached, entered and used conveniently by persons with a disability; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: complies with this Schedule;

section.def: accessible lift (暢通易達升降機) means a lift that complies with the requirements set out in Division 19 of Part 2;

assistive listening system (聆聽輔助系統) means a system that enables sound signs that are amplified in both volume and signal to be transmitted to persons with hearing impairment without interference from background noise or excessive reverberation;
common areas (公用地方), in relation to a building, means areas open to, and available for the common use and enjoyment of, all occupiers of the building;
persons with ambulant disabilities (行動困難的殘疾人士) means persons with ambulant impairment who require the aid of devices such as prostheses, orthoses, sticks or crutches for walking;
required staircase (規定的樓梯) means an access staircase in a firefighting and rescue stairway or a staircase which provides means of escape in case of fire;

tactile guide path (觸覺引路帶) means a standardized pattern applied to or built onto walking surfaces through the combined use of tactile directional tiles or blocks, positional tiles or blocks and tactile hazard warning tiles or blocks, as set out in Figure No. 1 and Figure No. 2 in Part 3 of this Schedule, for way finding and orientation for persons with visual impairment;

tactile warning strip (觸覺警示帶) means a standardized pattern applied to or built onto walking surfaces through the use of tactile hazard warning tiles or blocks, as set out in Figure No. 2 in Part 3 of this Schedule, to warn persons with visual impairment of certain construction features;
wheelchair users (坐輪椅人士) means persons who depend on wheelchairs for mobility.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application: Division 1, Part 2
section.leadIn: This Division applies to premises with auditorium, including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: theatres;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cinemas;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: concert halls;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: sports stadiums;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: games halls;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: lecture halls; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: conference halls.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Interpretation: Division 1, Part 2
section.content: In this Division, relevant activity (有關活動) means the activity for the purpose of which the audience in the premises attend the premises.

subsection.content: On any premises with an auditorium with not more than 800 fixed seats at spectator level, not less than 4 wheelchair spaces shall be provided at spectator level. (L.N. 205 of 2008)

On any premises with an auditorium with more than 800 fixed seats at spectator level, not less than 2 wheelchair spaces shall be provided at spectator level for every 400 fixed seats or any part thereof. (L.N. 205 of 2008)
A wheelchair space shall be adjacent to at least one other wheelchair space.
Wheelchair spaces shall be adjacent to fixed seats.
A wheelchair space shall have unobstructed view of the spot at which the relevant activity takes place.
The side of a wheelchair space facing the spot at which the relevant activity takes place shall be not less than 800 mm and the other side shall be not less than 1 300 mm.
A passage leading to a wheelchair space from an accessible entrance of an auditorium shall be not less than 1 500 mm in width.
Nothing in this section prohibits the installation of readily removable seats in the wheelchair spaces when the spaces are not occupied by wheelchair users.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Access for wheelchair users
section.leadIn: On premises to which this Division applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the auditorium, the stage, backstage facilities, changing rooms, rehearsal rooms, dressing rooms, rest rooms, toilets and shower rooms shall be accessible to wheelchair users; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an access connecting any 2 or more of them shall be an accessible route for wheelchair users.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Braille and tactile fire exit maps and tactile warning strips

subsection.content: Braille and tactile fire exit maps shall be provided at all entrances to an auditorium.
Tactile warning strips shall be provided at the top and bottom ends of the staircases leading to the stage.

def.name: AnAccessibleGuestRoom
def.leadIn: For the purposes of this section, an accessible guest room (暢通易達客房) means a room—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that is at an accessible location; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in which all sleeping, bathing and sanitary facilities are accessible.

subsection.content: Two accessible guest rooms shall be provided for every 100 guest rooms or part thereof in every hotel, hostel or guesthouse.
Accessible parking spaces shall be provided in every carpark.
The number of accessible parking spaces provided under subsection (1) shall conform to the table below.

td.center:
Minimum number of
accessible parking spaces

subsection.content: An accessible route between the accessible parking spaces and the lobby with an accessible lift or entrance shall be provided.
Subject to subsection (3), an accessible parking space shall be not less than 3 500 mm in width.
Where a loading or unloading area which complies with subsection (4) is provided between 2 accessible parking spaces, such parking spaces shall be not less than 2 500 mm in width.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (3), a loading or unloading area shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be not less than 1 200 mm in width; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be marked with yellow hatched markings.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Marking requirements for accessible parking spaces
section.leadIn: The floor of an accessible parking space shall be legibly marked with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a number assigned to the parking space; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the international symbol of accessibility as set out in Figure No. 3 in Part 3 of this Schedule, the size of which shall be not less than 1 500 mm × 1 500 mm.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), an access route shall be provided from a prominent point on the lot boundary, which is accessible to a public street or pedestrian way, directly—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an entrance which is commonly used by the public; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a point adjacent to an entrance which is commonly used by the public; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to an accessible lift.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply if providing an accessible entrance which is commonly used by the public at a prominent point on the lot boundary is impracticable because of difficult terrain or unusual characteristics of the site.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subsection (1) does not apply by virtue of subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the main entrance is not an accessible entrance,

subsection.continued: a vehicular access route to the building shall be provided and adequate directional signs shall be posted at a conspicuous location of the main entrance to show clearly the location of, and the route to, an accessible entrance.

subsection.content: The clear width of an access route shall be not less than 1 050 mm.

subsection.leadIn: An access route shall be free from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any object or feature which impedes the passage of a wheelchair; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other form of barrier which will prevent access by persons with a disability,

subsection.continued: except those objects, features or forms of barrier that comply with this Schedule.

subsection.content: The surface of an access route shall be firm.
This section applies to access routes provided for buildings specified in items 1, 4, 5, 7, 10, 11 and 13 in the table in Division 21.
An access route shall be provided with a tactile guide path arranged in conformity to Figure No. 4 in Part 3 of this Schedule.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Ramps to be provided
section.content: Ramps shall be provided at all changes in level other than those served by an accessible lift or accessible lifting mechanism accommodating the specific requirements of persons with a disability.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Width of ramps
section.content: Ramps shall be not less than 1 050 mm in width.

subsection.content: A clear level space of not less than 1 500 mm in width and in depth shall be provided at the head and foot of every ramp.
Door swings and similar objects shall not be allowed to swing into such landing space.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Running slope and length
section.leadIn: No ramp shall be steeper than 1 in 12 gradient except a single minor rise that conforms to the measurements set out in the table below.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), where the gradient of a ramp is 1 in 20 or steeper, the ramp shall be provided—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with a landing of not less than 1 200 mm in length for each 10 m length of horizontal run or part thereof;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on both sides with handrails that comply with Division 8; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: with tactile warning strips arranged in conformity to Figure No. 5 in Part 3 of this Schedule at the head, foot and landings.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a ramp access to lift; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a ramp less than 300 mm in length.

subsection.leadIn: Any ramp—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with a rise greater than 200 mm; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: leading down towards an area where there may be vehicular traffic,

subsection.continued: shall have a railing or barrier at a distance of not less than 1 500 mm from the foot of the ramp across the full width of the lower end of the ramp.

subsection.content: On the surface of a ramp, raised traction strips shall be avoided.
A kerb of not less than 100 mm in height, or a rail 200 mm above ramp level, shall be provided on both sides to prevent a wheelchair from slipping over the edge.

There shall be no appliances, fixtures or fittings projecting beyond 90 mm from the surface of any wall adjacent to a ramp below a level of 2 000 mm above the ramp level unless such appliances, fixtures or fittings are unavoidable on reasonable ground.

subsection.leadIn: Appliances, fixtures and fittings that are unavoidable on reasonable ground shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: extended downwards to the ramp level; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: guided by tactile flooring materials.

subsection.content: The floor and wall along ramps shall be in contrasting colours.

A dropped kerb in the form of a ramp shall be provided at a pedestrian crossing and at each end of a footpath of a private street or access road to accommodate the change in level towards a vehicular area.
A kerb separating a footpath or ramp from a vehicular area shall also be in the form of a dropped kerb.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Requirements for dropped kerbs
section.leadIn: Dropped kerbs shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not less than 1 200 mm in length and 1 200 mm in width;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provided with a clearance not less than 800 mm in length at the back of the footway;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: ramped at a gradient not steeper than 1 in 10;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: at a level difference of not more than 15 mm with the vehicular areas;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: provided with a tactile warning strip at 300 mm from the vehicular areas; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: provided with a tactile warning strip of a nominal width of 600 mm at the ramp.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Location of dropped kerbs
section.content: A dropped kerb shall be so located as to enable users to have an unobstructed view of traffic approaching from any direction.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Surface of dropped kerbs
section.content: On the surface of a dropped kerb, raised traction strips shall be avoided.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Application: Division 7, Part 2
section.content: This Division applies only to the required staircases and the main circulation staircase in the common areas of a building.

subsection.leadIn: A tread of a step in a staircase shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (in the case of internal staircases) not less than 225 mm in width measured from the face of one riser to the face of the next riser; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (in the case of external staircases) not less than 280 mm in width measured from the face of one riser to the face of the next riser.

subsection.content: A tread shall be provided with a non-slip nosing which is not a projecting nosing.
A nosing and the tread shall be in contrasting colours.
A tread and the adjacent wall shall be in contrasting colours.

subsection.leadIn: A riser of a step in a staircase shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (in the case of internal staircases) not more than 175 mm in height; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (in the case of external staircases) not more than 160 mm in height.

subsection.leadIn: A riser shall be built with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a vertical face; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a receding face not more than 15 mm from the point perpendicular to the edge of the nosing of the next higher tread.

subsection.content: A staircase shall be provided on both sides with properly fitted handrails.
A flight of staircase shall have not more than 16 steps.
For the purposes of subsection (8), steps between 2 landings shall be regarded as constituting a flight of staircase.

subsection.leadIn: Tactile warning strips arranged in conformity to Figure No. 6 in Part 3 of this Schedule shall be provided at—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: landings of a staircase; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: both the top and bottom ends of a staircase.

subsection.content: Tactile warning strips provided at landings leading to a floor or landings enclosed by wall, railing or balustrade shall be 300 mm in width.
Tactile warning strips provided at landings leading to an open space or the entrance or exit of a building shall be 600 mm in width.

Where tactile warning strips are provided at landings referred to in subsection (3), Braille and tactile information signs shall be provided on the adjacent wall to indicate the presence of an opening.
Tactile warning strips provided for a staircase with intermediate steps between the two flights shall be arranged in conformity to Figure No. 6 in Part 3 of this Schedule.

There shall be no appliances, fixtures or fittings projecting beyond 90 mm from the surface of any wall adjacent to a staircase below a level of 2 000 mm above the treads of the staircase unless such appliances, fixtures or fittings are unavoidable on reasonable ground.
Appliances, fixtures and fittings that are unavoidable on reasonable ground shall be extended downwards to the level of the treads.
A handrail to ramps and steps shall be fixed not less than 30 mm and not more than 50 mm clear of wall and with a clear height of 70 mm from the top of the bracket to the top of the handrail.
The top of a handrail shall be at a height of not less than 850 mm and not more than 950 mm above any nosing, floor or landing.

subsection.leadIn: A handrail shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: tubular; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other shapes that can provide the user a grip similar to that provided by a tubular handrail.

subsection.content: The external diameter of a handrail shall be not less than 32 mm and not more than 50 mm.

subsection.leadIn: A handrail shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: extend horizontally not less than 300 mm beyond the first and last nosing of every flight of staircase or beyond the ends of a ramp; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: terminate into a closed end, which shall turn down or return fully to end post or wall face and which shall not project into a route of travel.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding subsection (5)(a), where a door opening is in place, the horizontal extension may be shortened to not less than 100 mm.
A handrail shall be so installed as to resist a load of not less than 1.3 kN applied vertically or horizontally.
A handrail shall not be fitted in a manner that allows it to rotate within its fixing fittings.
Braille and tactile information on directional arrows and floor numbers shall be provided on handrails on every floor to facilitate persons with visual impairment.
Where directional signs exist on handrails, Braille and tactile information shall also be provided in conformity to Figure No. 6 in Part 3 of this Schedule.
A corridor, lobby, path or similar space shall have a clear width of not less than 1 050 mm.
A space of not less than 1 500 mm in width and in depth shall be provided within 3 500 mm of a corridor, lobby or path where the means of exit for persons with a disability is in one direction only.
A lobby in a corridor shall be not less than 1 200 mm in length (excluding space for door swings).
A level area extending not less than 1 200 mm beyond the swings of the doors and not less than 1 500 mm in width shall be provided on both sides of every entrance of a building.
This section does not apply to lobbies which lead to staircases only.
Covers to channels on footpaths shall be flush with the surface of the footpaths.
The dimension of any hole in such cover or between such covers shall be not more than 20 mm.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Gratings
section.leadIn: Slots of gratings shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have a width of not more than 13 mm; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not be parallel to the pedestrian travel path.

subsection.content: There shall be no appliances, fixtures or fittings projecting beyond 90 mm from the surface of any wall adjacent to corridors, lobbies or paths below a level of 2 000 mm above the finished floor level unless such appliances, fixtures or fittings are unavoidable on reasonable ground.

subsection.leadIn: Appliances, fixtures and fittings that are unavoidable on reasonable ground shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: extended downwards to the finished floor level; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: guided by tactile flooring materials.

def.name: ControlledPassage
def.leadIn: In this section, controlled passage (受管制通道) means—

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: a cashier counter at a shop;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: a passage through anti-theft device installed at a shop; or

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: a turnstile-controlled passage accessible to the public.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (4), a path shall be provided at each controlled passage for the use by wheelchair users.

subsection.leadIn: A path so provided shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not less than 800 mm in width; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: clearly marked with the international symbol of accessibility as set out in Figure No. 3 in Part 3 of this Schedule.

subsection.content: Subsection (2) does not apply if an alternative passage for wheelchair users adjacent to the controlled passage is provided.
Where a headroom does not exceed 2 000 mm from the finished floor level, a warning guardrail or other barrier shall be provided for detection.
The leading edge of a warning guardrail or barrier shall be at or below 680 mm above the finished floor level.

section.name: s37
section.heading: Application: Division 10, Part 2
section.content: This Division applies to doors on accessible routes.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Width of doors
section.leadIn: A door shall have a clear width of not less than 800 mm between the open door and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the opposite jamb; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the door is one leaf of a pair of double doors, the other leaf.

subsection.leadIn: An unobstructed area which is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not less than 330 mm in width; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: adjacent to the door handle on the leading face of a single door,

subsection.content: A door which is less than 330 mm from the corner of a room shall be so constructed and installed that it swings from the side nearer to that corner.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Double-action self-closing doors
section.leadIn: A double-action self-closing door shall have—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a check mechanism that is designed to prevent the door swinging beyond the closed position; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a transparent vision-panel with a bottom edge not more than 1 000 mm above the finished floor level and a top edge not less than 1 500 mm above the finished floor level.

section.name: s41
section.heading: Handles
section.content: A door handle shall be not less than 950 mm and not more than 1 050 mm above the finished floor level, measured from the top surface of the grip.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Door thresholds
section.leadIn: A door threshold shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not more than 20 mm in height; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: bevelled to facilitate passage of wheelchairs.

subsection.def: For the purposes of this section, a door closing device (關門機掣) includes a door closer, spring hinge and floor hinge.

subsection.leadIn: A door closing device shall be so designed as to allow the door to be opened with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (in the case of an interior door) a horizontal force of not more than 22 N; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (in the case of an exterior door) a horizontal force of not more than 30 N.

subsection.content: A door required to have fire resistance period installed along an accessible route shall be so designed as to allow it to be opened with a horizontal force of not more than 30 N.

A door closer for an interior door shall have a closing period of at least 3 seconds measured from an open position of 70o to a point 75 mm from the closed position measured from the leading edge of the door.
A frameless glass door and the glass panel adjacent to it (if any) shall be prominently marked so as to make them conspicuous.
At least a portion of the marking shall be placed not less than 900 mm and not more than 1 500 mm above the finished floor level.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sports stadiums;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: town halls;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: civic centres;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: theatres;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: museums;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: public libraries;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: shopping complexes;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: sports complexes;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: public swimming pool complexes;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: office buildings;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: hotels; and

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: hospitals.

subsection.leadIn: An automatic door shall be installed at—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the only main entrance of a building; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least one of the main entrances of a building which is commonly used by the public,

section.name: s46
section.heading: Provision of accessible water closet cubicle

subsection.leadIn: This section does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: domestic buildings and domestic parts of composite buildings; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a floor in a building on which no toilet is provided.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), where the total number of water closet cubicles provided on a floor—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is 20 or less, at least one accessible water closet cubicle shall be provided on that floor; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exceeds 20, at least 2 accessible water closet cubicles shall be provided on that floor.

subsection.content: If an accessible water closet cubicle provided on a floor is provided in a toilet with multiple cubicles, subsection (2) has effect as if a reference to a floor in that subsection was a reference to a toilet with multiple cubicles.
For the purposes of subsection (2), floor (樓層) includes a part of a floor designed for access by persons with a disability.
Where toilet is provided on a floor, at least one toilet shall be designed as an accessible unisex sanitary facility for use by persons of both sexes.
An accessible unisex toilet provided under subsection (1) shall be so located that access to it does not necessitate traversing an area reserved for one sex only.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Location of accessible water closet cubicle

subsection.leadIn: An accessible water closet cubicle provided in a toilet with multiple cubicles shall be accessible—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: through a clear space of not less than 1 500 mm in width and in depth immediately in front of the cubicle; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by direct approach where no turning of the wheelchair is necessary.

subsection.content: An accessible water closet cubicle that is not provided in a toilet with multiple cubicles shall be accessible directly from a public corridor.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Design of accessible water closet cubicle

subsection.content: The internal area of an accessible water closet cubicle shall be not less than 1 500 mm × 1 750 mm.
The clear manoeuvring space within an accessible water closet cubicle shall be not less than 1 500 mm × 1 500 mm in area measured at 350 mm above the finished floor level.

subsection.leadIn: An accessible water closet cubicle shall have in it a water closet—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at a height of not less than 380 mm and not more than 450 mm, measured to the top of the toilet seat;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: equipped with a back support such as a seat lid; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the seat of which shall not be spring-actuated.

subsection.content: This section applies to flushing controls in accessible water closet cubicles.

subsection.leadIn: A flushing control shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: mounted on the wide side of the cubicle at a height of not less than 600 mm and not more than 1 050 mm above the finished floor level; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: hand-operated or automatic.

subsection.leadIn: A hand-operated flushing control shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be capable of being operated with one hand;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not require tight grasping, pinching or twisting of the wrist; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be able to be operated with a force not greater than 22 N.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Wash basins in toilets with accessible water closet cubicle

subsection.content: This section applies to wash basins in toilets with accessible water closet cubicle.
A toilet with accessible water closet cubicle shall be provided with a wash basin mounted with the rim at a height of not more than 750 mm above the finished floor level.
There shall be a clearance of 550 mm from the finished floor level to the bottom of the apron of a wash basin.
Subject to the approval of the Director of Water Supplies, the tap for a wash basin shall be automatic or of lever control type without spring loading.

subsection.leadIn: The tap for a wash basin shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not require tight grasping, pinching or twisting of the wrist; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be able to be operated with a force not greater than 22 N.

subsection.content: A wash basin shall be capable of carrying a static load of 150 kg.

subsection.leadIn: The door of an accessible water closet cubicle or a toilet with such cubicle shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: installed with push-type or lever-type handle on both sides of the door; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: capable of being easily opened or closed by one hand.

subsection.content: The door fastening of a door referred to in subsection (1) shall be capable of being released from the outside in the event of an emergency.
No coin box shall be affixed to the door of an accessible water closet cubicle.

subsection.leadIn: Inside an accessible water closet cubicle, there shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (2), at least one horizontal grab rail of not less than 600 mm in length and at least one vertical grab rail of not less than 600 mm in length arranged in L-shaped configuration fixed on the wall facing one side of the water closet; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: one folding grab rail fixed on the wall at the back of the water closet which can be lowered to provide support on the other side of the water closet.

subsection.content: The requirement of subsection (1)(a) is to be regarded as being satisfied if an L-shaped grab rail which is not less than 1 200 mm in length is fixed on the wall facing the side of the water closet.
A folding grab rail shall be so fixed that it is at a height of not less than 725 mm and not more than 750 mm above the finished floor level when lowered from the wall.
A notice containing simple instructions in English, Chinese and Braille on how to unfold a folding grab rail shall be affixed to the wall on which the rail is fixed.

subsection.leadIn: There shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a horizontal grab rail fixed on the inner surface of the door of an accessible water closet cubicle; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a horizontal grab rail fixed on the outer surface of such door.

subsection.leadIn: A grab rail fixed in compliance with this section shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be not less than 32 mm and not more than 40 mm in external diameter;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be so fixed that a grip space of not less than 30 mm clear of the wall or door surface is left; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: not be fitted in a manner that allows it to rotate within its fixing fittings.

subsection.leadIn: A grab rail referred to in subsection (1) shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not less than 600 mm in length; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: capable of carrying a static load of 150 kg.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Emergency call bell
section.content: An emergency call bell that complies with Division 17 shall be provided in an accessible water closet cubicle.

subsection.leadIn: If more than one urinal is provided, at least one urinal shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have a clear levelled space of not less than 800 mm in width and not less than 1 500 mm in depth in front of the urinal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be wall hung urinal with a front rim at a height of not more than 400 mm above the finished floor level.

subsection.content: Vertical grab rails shall be fixed on both sides of a urinal referred to in subsection (1) on the wall on which the urinal is mounted for use by persons with ambulant disabilities.

subsection.leadIn: A grab rail shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have an external diameter of not less than 32 mm and not more than 40 mm;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be not less than 600 mm in length; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be at a height of 1 200 mm above the finished floor level.

division.name: D12
division.heading: —Bathrooms and Shower Compartments in Accessible Guest Rooms

section.name: s55A
section.heading: Application: Division 12, Part 2
section.content: This Division applies to bathrooms and shower compartments in accessible guest rooms required under section 7.

subsection.content: There shall be a clear floor space of not less than 1 500 mm in width and 800 mm in depth in front of the bathtub in an accessible bathroom.
A bathtub shall be provided with a seat of not less than 250 mm in width.
A bathtub shall have a height of not more than 380 mm.
A grab rail shall be fixed on the wall along the length of a bathtub in an accessible bathroom.

subsection.leadIn: A grab rail shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not less than 900 mm in length;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fixed horizontally or slanting at an angle not exceeding 20o; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: at a height of not less than 150 mm and not more than 300 mm above the rim of the bathtub.

subsection.content: A vertical grab rail of not less than 600 mm in length shall be fixed on the wall at the plug end of the bathtub adjacent to the clear floor space referred to in section 56(1).
The lower end of a vertical grab rail referred to in subsection (3) shall be not less than 150 mm and not more than 300 mm above the rim of the bathtub.

subsection.leadIn: A grab rail referred to in subsection (1) or (3) shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have an external diameter of not less than 32 mm and not more than 40 mm;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be so fixed that a grip space of not less than 30 mm clear of the wall is left; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: not be fitted in a manner that allows it to rotate within its fixing fittings.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Taps and controls of bathtubs
section.leadIn: Taps and other controls of a bathtub in an accessible bathroom shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have lever type handle the length of which shall not be less than 75 mm measured from the centre of rotation to the handle tip;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be installed at the plug end of the bathtub; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be not more than 450 mm above the rim of the bathtub.

subsection.leadIn: A shower head for a bathtub in an accessible bathroom shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of the hand-held type;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provided with a hose not less than 1 500 mm in length; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provided with a bracket mounted on the wall to allow use in a fixed position.

subsection.leadIn: Where a shower head is mounted on a vertical bar, the bar shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not less than 500 mm in length, with the lower end not less than 450 mm above the finished floor level;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: so installed that the use of grab rails referred to in section 57 is not obstructed; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: capable of carrying a static load of 150 kg.

subsection.content: An accessible shower compartment shall have internal dimensions of not less than 1 500 mm in width and not less than 900 mm in depth.
A clear floor space of not less than 1 500 mm × 800 mm with the dimension parallel to the shower entrance being not less than 1 500 mm shall be provided in front of the entrance of the compartment.
A horizontal grab rail not less than 900 mm in length shall be fixed on the wall on which the taps and other controls in an accessible shower compartment are mounted.
A horizontal grab rail of not less than 750 mm in length shall be fixed on the wall next to the wall referred to in subsection (1).

The requirements of subsections (1) and (2) can also be satisfied by fixing on the 2 walls referred to in those subsections a horizontal L-shaped grab rail provided that if the 2 sections of the rail were separate rails, they both satisfy the requirements of those subsections.

subsection.leadIn: A grab rail shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have an external diameter of not less than 32 mm and not more than 40 mm;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be at a height of not less than 700 mm and not more than 800 mm above the finished floor level;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: have a grip space of not less than 30 mm clear from the wall;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: not be fitted in a manner that allows it to rotate within its fixed fittings; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: be capable of carrying a static load of 150 kg.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Thresholds of accessible shower compartments
section.leadIn: Thresholds of accessible shower compartments shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be not more than 13 mm in height; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: have bevelled edges.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Shower seats
section.leadIn: A shower seat provided in an accessible shower compartment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have a rounded edge;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be self-draining;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be installed on the wall adjacent to the wall on which the taps and other controls are mounted;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: be not less than 550 mm in width and 400 mm in depth; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: shall be installed at a height of not less than 430 mm and not more than 480 mm measured from the top of the seat to the finished floor level.

section.name: s64
section.heading: International symbol of accessibility
section.leadIn: The international symbol of accessibility as set out in Figure No. 3 in Part 3 of this Schedule shall be provided at conspicuous location for the purposes of indicating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: accessible entrances to the building;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: accessible exits from the building;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: car parking facilities reserved for persons with a disability;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the location of toilets for persons with a disability;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: usable vertical circulation facilities;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: usable cloakroom facilities; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the availability of special services of information or service counters and telephones in the building.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Directional signs
section.content: Directional arrows and visual information shall be provided at conspicuous locations in conjunction with the international symbol of accessibility to guide persons with a disability to the exact locations of the accessible facilities.

subsection.content: This section applies to signs displayed in compliance with this Division.
The height of signs displayed on doors shall be not less than 60 mm.
The height of signs displayed in corridors shall be not less than 110 mm.
The height of signs displayed at external locations shall be not less than 200 mm.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Signs for persons with hearing impairment
section.content: The international symbol of access for hearing loss as set out in Figure No. 7 in Part 3 of this Schedule shall be provided if there is an assistive listening system provided for persons with hearing impairment.

subsection.content: Braille and tactile signs shall be fixed on adjacent walls or doors of a public toilet to indicate whether the toilet is for male, female or unisex.
Such signs shall be placed at a height of not less than 900 mm and not more than 1 500 mm above the finished floor level.
If a public toilet has no door, such signs shall be fixed on the toilet front wall.

A Braille and tactile fire exit map shall be provided directly above the call button of the accessible lift in the lobby of that lift in a building if a fire exit map for the use of the public is provided.
Such map shall be placed at a height of not less than 800 mm and not more than 1 200 mm above the finished floor level.

division.name: D14
division.heading: Special Design Requirements to Assist Persons with Visual or Hearing Impairment

section.name: s69
section.heading: Special design requirements to assist persons with visual or hearing impairment

subsection.content: This section applies to any part of a building used for the purposes as specified in Division 21.

If a floor plan for the use of the public is provided, Braille and tactile floor plan showing the main entrance, public toilet and major common facilities shall be provided in a place in that building which is conspicuous to persons with visual impairment.

subsection.leadIn: Tactile guide path shall be installed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: from a point of access at the lot boundary to the main entrance of the building; and

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: lift zone;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the nearest accessible toilet;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the nearest public information or service counter;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the nearest Braille and tactile floor plan; and

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: the nearest staircase.

subsection.content: If a visual display board is provided, it shall be able to display the essence of the information broadcasted by the public address system in the building, if any.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Provision of public information or service counters

subsection.content: There shall be public information or service counters in buildings specified in Division 21.

subsection.leadIn: In every building there shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at least one public information or service counter built with a portion not more than 750 mm in height above the finished floor level and not less than 750 mm in width to assist wheelchair users; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least one public information or service counter provided with an assistive listening system where the surrounding environment is noisy or where a screen is installed at the counter.

subsection.content: A public information or service counter shall be accessible and easily identifiable from the building entrance by persons with a disability.

subsection.leadIn: Leg space of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not less than 400 mm and not more than 600 mm in depth; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not less than 680 mm in height above the finished floor level,

subsection.continued: shall be provided at a public information or service counter.

subsection.content: The ground floor entrance lobby and the lifts in a building shall, when they are reasonably expected to be used by the public during the period of normal use or occupation or when required, have illumination level of not less than 120 lux measured at the finished floor level at the centre point of the lobby or lift, as the case may be.

The lift lobby of a floor other than the ground floor of a building shall, when it is reasonably expected to be used by the public during the period of normal use or occupation or when required, have illumination level of not less than 85 lux measured at the finished floor level at the centre point of the lobby.

The corridors, accessible paths and staircases in a building shall, when they are reasonably expected to be used by the public during the period of normal use or occupation or when required, have illumination level of not less than 85 lux measured at the finished floor level along the centre line of the corridor, path or staircase, as the case may be.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Illumination level for signs
section.content: Signs provided in compliance with Division 13 shall have illumination level on the sign surface of not less than 120 lux.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Means of provision of illumination
section.content: The illumination may be provided through automatic or manual switching devices.

division.name: D17
division.heading: Emergency Call Bells in Accessible Toilets

section.name: s75
section.heading: Emergency call bells in accessible toilets

subsection.content: An emergency call bell shall be installed for every accessible water closet cubicle required under Division 11.
An emergency call bell when activated shall emit audible or visible alarm signal which shall be readily noticeable for summoning assistance for the people in the accessible toilet.
Subject to subsection (4), an alarm of an emergency call bell shall be installed outside the accessible toilet.
Subsection (3) does not apply if a buzzer which emits audible signal when the emergency call bell is activated is fitted in the caretaker’s office in the building.

section.name: s76
section.heading: Push button for emergency call bell

subsection.content: An emergency call bell required under section 75(1) shall be equipped with a waterproof push button for activating the alarm.

The push button shall be installed below the vertical grab rail inside the water closet cubicle adjacent to the water closet at a height of not less than 600 mm and not more than 650 mm above the finished floor level.
A notice containing the words “Emergency Call”, the characters “緊急召援” and Braille to the like effect shall be fitted next to the push button.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Assistive listening system
section.leadIn: An assistive listening system (such as an induction loop system or an infra-red system) shall be provided in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at least one of the public information or service counters, if any, in any building belonging to the categories of buildings set out in Division 21; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the hall and auditorium, if any, of such a building.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), every floor of a building shall be accessible by at least one passenger lift which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has internal car dimensions of not less than 1 100 mm in width and not less than 1 200 mm in depth;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has a clear entrance of not less than 850 mm in width; and

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: which extends to within 150 mm of the corners at the rear and sides of the car;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the top of the gripping surface of which is at a height of not less than 850 mm and not more than 950 mm above the finished floor level; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: which is so fitted that a space of not less than 30 mm and not more than 50 mm is left between the handrails and wall.

subsection.leadIn: Where there are more than 3 lifts in a building, access shall be provided to every floor by at least one lift which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has internal car dimensions of not less than 1 500 mm × 1 400 mm (in either width or depth); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has a clear entrance of not less than 850 mm in width.

subsection.content: Lift car doors and landing doors shall be of the horizontally sliding type, power-operated and automatically controlled.
An audible signal shall be provided to signify the closing of the doors to alert persons.
A detection device shall be provided to re-open the lift doors if the closing lift doors hit any obstacle.
Such detection device shall be positioned at not less than 500 mm and not more than 600 mm above the floor of the lift car.

subsection.leadIn: The—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: floor numbering buttons;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: emergency call bell push buttons; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: door opening push buttons,

subsection.continued: in a lift car shall be not less than 900 mm and not more than 1 200 mm above the floor of the car.

subsection.content: The lift call buttons at a lift lobby shall be not less than 900 mm and not more than 1 200 mm above the finished floor level of the lobby.
Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to secondary control panels for over-spilled floor numbering buttons.
All buttons referred to in subsections (1) and (2) shall have a dimension of not less than 20 mm.

subsection.leadIn: Braille and tactile markings shall be placed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the buttons referred to in subsections (1) and (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to the left of such buttons.

subsection.leadIn: The Braille and tactile markings shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have a dimension of not less than 15 mm in height; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be raised not less than 1 mm.

subsection.content: The tactile markings for push buttons for the main entrance floor shall be identified with a symbol in a star shape.
An emergency call bell push button shall be identified with a symbol in a bell shape.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Indication and notification for accessible lifts

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), an illuminated visual indicator and an audible signal shall be provided at a lift entrance to indicate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the arrival of the lift car; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the direction of travel of the lift car.

subsection.leadIn: The audible signal shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be activated before the arrival of the lift car at the floor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sound once if the lift car is moving upward; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: sound twice if the lift car is moving downward.

subsection.content: The audible signal can be generated by a device in the lift car provided that it can be heard from the lift lobby.
Tactile and Braille floor designations shall be provided on the jambs on both sides of each lift entrance by means of Arabic numerals.

subsection.leadIn: Such floor designations shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not less than 60 mm in height;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: raised 1 mm; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: at 1 200 mm above the finished floor level of the lift lobby.

subsection.leadIn: Illuminated visual position indicators shall be provided in a lift car to indicate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the direction of travel of the lift car; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the position of the lift car.

subsection.content: The indicating numerals or signs on the illuminated visual position indicator shall be not less than 50 mm in height.
An audio indication in English, Cantonese and Putonghua of the stopping floor shall be provided.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Identification of accessible lifts in lift lobbies

subsection.content: If not all lifts in a building comply with this Division, each of the lifts that comply with this Division shall be identified, by at least one international symbol of accessibility (as set out in Figure No. 3 in Part 3 of this Schedule), at each landing served by the lift.

If the only lift or all the lifts, as may be appropriate, in a building comply with this Division, at least one international symbol of accessibility (as set out in Figure No. 3 in Part 3 of this Schedule) shall be provided at each lift lobby on the entrance level of the building.

section.name: s84
section.heading: Requirements for escalators and passenger conveyors
section.content: Adequate warning or guarding shall be provided alongside and at each end of escalators and passenger conveyors for the safety of persons with visual impairment.

subsection.content: Tactile warning strips arranged in conformity to Figure No. 8 in Part 3 of this Schedule shall be provided at the top and bottom ends of an escalator. (17 of 2018 s. 54)
Tactile warning strips arranged in conformity to Figure No. 8 in Part 3 of this Schedule shall be provided at both ends of a passenger conveyor.

part.text: The figure shows the three kinds of tactile tiles or blocks commonly used in constructing a tactile guide path. Directional tile or block has parallel raised bars for guiding the users along an intended safe path. Hazard warning tile or block has raised big dots (35 mm in diameter) arranged in square grid parallel to the sides of the slab for indication of potential hazards ahead. This type of tile or block can be used alone to form tactile warning strips at the top and bottom ends of staircase or ramps, and at dropped kerb. Positional tile or block has raised small dots (23 mm in diameter) placed in staggered positions for indication of possible change in walking directions.
